segments.text: Welcome back to hashtag sisters-in-law with Jill Wine Banks, Kimberly at can store, Joyce
Vance and me, Barb McQuaid.
Since the holiday season is approaching, you know what time it is, it is time to order
your hashtag sisters-in-law merch.
Go to politicon.com slash merch where you can get yourself a hashtag sisters-in-law,
t-shirt, hoodie, water bottle and much more.
Well today we will be discussing the departure of Cheryl and Eiffel as the executive director
of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, the different standards to which women and men are held in
public life, and diversity on corporate boards.
And as always, we'll look forward to answering your questions at the end of the show.
But first, you know, this was Thanksgiving week.
We all, I trust, had a joyful Thanksgiving, and I just wanted to ask each of you, maybe
something that you're thankful for.
And you know, you can't say like, you know, my family and my health, you know, you're
thankful for all those things, and that's wonderful.
And of course we all are.
But what else are you thankful for?
Kim, how about you?
Well, okay, so this one's kind of technically related to both my family and my health, but
I'm thankful that the, that boosters have been available, are now available to everyone
that, and that's really going to help throughout the rest of the holiday season.
People really feel confident in getting together and celebrating and having something that
feels a little more like normal than the last two years has given us.
It, you know, my parents are boosted.
I'm boosted.
That gives me a boost.
So I'm very grateful for that.
How about you Joyce?
I'm super grateful that my best friend hosted Thanksgiving, that although I cooked and made
a turkey and all the fixings, she did all of the setup and the cleanup and I sat around
and watched football.
So I know that sort of shallow, but shout out to Eva.
I'm incredibly grateful.
Jill, what about you?
Well, I know you said I couldn't say this, but I am incredibly grateful for my sisters
in law, for my quince, who are a group I have weekly conversations with that are extremely
challenging and energizing, for my bridesmaid's friends, which is a very special group of friends
that I travel with every year and see regularly, for my Iota friends, which is my college sorority
friends.
So we have been friends, we graduated in, I can't even say the year, but it's older
than most of our listeners are.
So I'm really grateful for that.
And of course for my husband and my neighbors, all the good things in life really are the
people in my life.
And so what about you Barb?
Yeah, that's tough to top, Jill.
I think all of us are very thankful for our families and our friends.
Those are the things that make us go.
And our listeners, I think we're all thankful to our listeners.
Yes, yes, yes.
Very grateful.
I want to say that I'm thankful for the concept of gratitude itself.
Bear with me here.
I have a friend named Gary who has made it his practice to give people he knows in his
life, gratitude journals.
And I'm sure you've become familiar with this concept.
But if you write down every day to something that you're grateful for, it really does help
put into perspective how unimportant so many of the worries that we have are.
Because those are the kinds of things that I end up writing down in the book, things about
family and health and the things that are really important.
And when you focus on those things, then a lot of the little frustrations of the day
pale by comparison.
So I think I'm grateful for gratitude.
How about that?
That makes me want to try doing that.
What a great idea.
Yeah.
I've never done that.
But what you said really made me think about our audience and how grateful I am for that.
And for just having the opportunity instead of yelling at the television set and being
upset, I get to actually say something out loud that may help other people deal with
the horrible news that we get every day.
And that makes me very grateful to be able to have an opportunity to have a voice.
I still yell at my television when I'm watching Alliance play.
But let's get into our conversation.
Jill, I think you're going to lead us through our first topic.
Right.
The first one is something that we're also grateful for, which is Sheryl and Eiffel.
And it's one of the many things that we have to think about.
I bet our listeners already know about Sheryl and her work.
But just for the record, Sheryl and is both a law professor and the president and director
council of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund.
She is the seventh president since Thurgood Marshall, one of my heroes of all legal times,
founded the organization in 1940.
I wasn't around then.
I'm old, but I'm not that old.
But he was just one of the most amazing people.
And their goal was to secure full and fair access to the democratic citizenship by promoting
equality in education, voting, and political participation, economic justice, and criminal
justice.
LDF remains one of America's most preeminent civil rights organizations.
And it is also a law firm.
It's one of the biggest law firms that is working to fight for racial justice.
Under Sheryl and leadership, the organization has grown and accomplished great things.
But she recently announced her decision to turn over the reins to Janai Nelson, who Sheryl
and has mentored for many years now as her successor.
Janai will become the third female to lead the Legal Defense Fund.
Elaine Jones was the first, and of course, Sheryl and the second.
And of course, that's another thing that we should be grateful for.
But I really want to talk about Sheryl and the legislation and the expansion of LDF during
her tenure.
And also because some of you really know her quite well personally.
I'd like to have you talk about your personal reflections on her.
So should I start with you, Joyce?
You know, sure.
I'll start.
And I tried to think through some of the things that Sheryl and has worked on that I think
have been the most impactful.
Because what a lot of people don't know about her is she's a legal scholar.
I mean, she is a sure enough, legit, you know, legal scholar.
But she also understands how to use the law to achieve results.
And so one of the most important things that she did was she led the efforts to challenge
voter suppression in the wake of the Shelby County ruling, the Alabama case that gutted
the Voting Rights Act.
That ruling came down shortly after she began her tenure.
And LDF has litigated aggressively across the country.
It's litigated here in Alabama.
She's been both a moral voice insisting that we continue the work, but a voice of hope,
constantly evolving the fight and finding new ways to litigate and to litigate successfully
at points in time where we thought the law just would no longer permit us to move.
And she has even learned to take losses and to use them to get people to really encourage
people to continue activism when we feel like the courts won't get us there.
I have enormous respect for the fact that the woman never gives up.
She also led efforts to stop racist policing after Ferguson.
She was a real champion for the use of Title VI, which is the pattern or practice procedures
that we're now also familiar with, right?
We've seen Merrick Garland's Justice Department open more pattern and practice cases in its
first few months in effect than we saw in the entire four years of the Trump administration,
where Jeff Sessions essentially said, we're not going to do that kind of work anymore.
We're pro-cop and shut down all of that work.
Well, Cherylin was an early champion of that work.
You know, she's also been a voice that's insisted on expanding diversity on the federal bench.
She, a lot of the work she's done in that area, we're seeing now come to fruition with the
Biden administration's very diverse appointments, which are including more defense lawyers
and civil rights lawyers than we've ever seen before.
But I think, you know, the thing that I remember the most is that she was a strong voice.
She steered the civil rights community through the Trump administration, which frankly took
a hammer to nearly every civil rights, you know, law and regulation on the books.
And she was fierce and she was loyal and she was determined and she was the kind of
leader that other leaders in the civil rights community could look to.
So look, I'm clearly a Cherylin fan girl, right?
I mean, I think she's the lawyer that I aspire to be.
And I hope that there are a lot of other people out there who aspire to have that level of
fire as they do this work.
Yeah, you know, Joyce, it's interesting that you say that she's the type of lawyer that
you aspire to be.
I obviously have had two main careers, one as an attorney and one as a journalist and
two of the people who served as among my icons in both of those careers.
One was when I fall, the lake when I fall.
And the other is her cousin, Cherylin, one on the journalism side and one on the legal
side.
She, Cherylin really is our modern day, Thurgood Marshall.
I hope people appreciate that she is here and she is doing that now.
You know, everything you say about the work that she's doing is important, but part of
that role is being in the face of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund.
But as she served and she did it, you know, with with with gusto, I mean, I saw her because
she speaks at events.
She does media.
She's very media savvy.
She knows how to bring attention to an issue, but she's not bringing attention to herself.
She's bringing she's using she's mustering all of that savviness to bring the attention
to the issues that are needed in a way that I've just found so important and so on inspiring.
And I really wish in a perfect world, which we don't live in, her career will be topped
off the same way that Justice Marshall's would be on the nation's highest court.
We're not in a political reality where such a nomination would be made.
And if it were made probably unlikely to be confirmed and that's a real shame and that's
a loss for the nation.
If that's not a reason to vote democratic in the midterms, I don't know what is because
Cheryl and I for belongs on the Supreme Court.
Indeed.
Well, I'll just add to the reflections that that you both have have made.
One of the things that impressed me most is during the Trump administration, one of the
things that Cheryl and I for spoke out about is challenging members of our profession,
the legal profession to say, where have you been?
We need lawyers to speak out and stand up in defense of the rule of law.
And this is not a political issue.
Regardless of where you are on politics, if you are a lawyer, you know that we have a
constitution and we have a rule of law and to allow that to be thwarted to advance a
political agenda is just anathema to our constitutional system of government.
And so she was very strong in speaking out about that.
And I will say listening to her helped me find my voice a bit.
So I think it takes courageous leaders to inspire other people.
And she certainly is one of those.
So I have some more questions, but I want to say, Kim, you mentioned her cousin, Gwen,
who was also someone I admired greatly.
And one of my hopes is not only that she could end up, that Cheryl and could end up on the
Supreme Court, but that she could also end up on a US stamp because her cousin, Gwen,
is on a stamp.
And I save them to use for very special mailings.
And it's their heart to come by now.
I haven't been able to get them, but that would be really wonderful.
But let's talk about her successor.
And Joyce, again, I think you know her.
So if you could maybe talk a little bit about what you know about how she will be as the
new leader of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund.
Yeah, you know, Jenai has been the associate director of the Inc Fund.
And she's obviously been Cheryl and Lieutenant, but she's a seasoned litigator in her own right.
She was the, you know, key voice in Veezy versus Abbott.
Everybody knows the name Abbott.
Now the Texas governor, who we've spent a lot of time talking about in 2018, she ran the
successful federal challenge to Texas's voter ID law.
That was a law that Texas put in place that made it very restrictive.
The types of ID you had to show to be able to vote.
Big success there.
She was also the lead architect of of null versus Trump, which was the 2020 case that
sought to declare Trump's executive order banning diversity and equity and inclusion
training in the workplace unconstitutional.
Ultimately, Trump actually rescinded that that order.
And I know Jenai is careful never to take credit for that.
But I think she deserves a lot of credit.
So she's again, like Cheryl, and she's an academic.
She's somebody who continues to research and write in areas that are very complicated.
She does a lot of work in very complicated voting rights issues.
And she's conversant with Jerry Mandarin.
I think that that's a really good indication if you wanted to read the tea leaves of where
the the LDFC is its primary work heading in the next few years.
But I'm also certain that she'll continue Cheryl and commitment to education work and
to housing work.
I think she's going to be an extraordinary leader.
And I'm really looking forward to seeing what she does.
Sure sounds like the LDF is in very good hands now and coming to the future.
What kind of challenges do you think LDF faces?
Are there some issues that are going to be particularly tough in the coming years?
Yeah, you know, I think that all of the issues that the LDF focuses on will be tough in the coming years.
I mean, if you look at the pillars that Joyce laid out of the organization,
take criminal justice, the last two years have demonstrated to us how urgent the need
for criminal justice reforms, how urgent that need is from everything,
from pushing to end qualified immunity for police officers,
something that's been stubbornly difficult to push for legislation that can bring about
fewer deaths of unarmed people, particularly people of color, to everything from the
entire interaction that people have with the criminal justice system, from post-release
opportunity to mass incarceration, over incarceration, sentencing reform.
There's so much to be done there.
Economic justice, Joyce mentioned housing.
That is a critical issue right now, particularly as we come out of the pandemic
and the pandemic relief that was issued has been lifted.
We see evictions at an all-time high.
We see all kinds of disparities there, education disparities.
And I think most importantly, political participation, just protecting democracy,
voting rights will be job one.
I'm very happy to know that that is on the front burner for LDF right now,
protecting democracy, making sure that everyone has access to the vote.
So there is a lot to be done right now.
Cherylin did a lot, but the state of our nation means that there's still so much work to be done.
And what about, Barb, I'd like to ask you about some other individuals and organizations
who have dedicated themselves to the same sort of social justice causes.
And I know you have some favorites.
I thought that maybe you could mention some of those other organizations as we reflect back
on Thanksgiving and what we're thankful for for some of the other organizations
that deserve recognition for what they've done.
Well, you know, Jill, no discussion of social justice is complete without an appropriate
homage to Ms. Gloria Steinem, who is, you know, a role model and hero of mine as a young child.
I remember seeing her on the front lines of the women's liberation movement in the 60s and 70s.
And so I, when I think about the many strides that women have made, I think about her
and others who have advanced the cause, the national organization for women
and others who have done so much to advance the cause for women.
But, you know, there are a lot of organizations that are out there that do similar work
to what the NAACP Legal Defense Fund does, which is to bring impact litigation.
And this is a really important part of our legal system.
You know, I think sometimes in America, we criticize our litigious nature.
You know, we bring lawsuits for everything.
We bring lawsuits when somebody serves our coffee too hot and we spill it on ourselves.
But litigation, impact litigation, has a very important role in society.
And there are organizations that really focus on bringing these cases when they see an unjust law.
They look for opportunities to bring it.
They look for a sympathetic plaintiff and they file lawsuits.
You know, the ACLU is one of these groups, the National Health Law Program,
Land, Lambda Legal for the LGBTQ community and Planned Parenthood for reproductive rights.
You know, one of the landmark cases in women's reproductive rights is in addition to Roe
versus Wade, which gets most of the mileage and was the, you know, the big one
that set out this right against abortion restrictions until viability was Planned Parenthood versus Casey.
And this is the big case that challenged a law in Pennsylvania that the holding of which is
that states cannot place undue burdens on people seeking abortions.
So these organizations are out there doing really great work.
They are very worthy of our notice and attention and our funds.
If you're looking for organizations to support, there are many of them and there are really,
these are great jobs for lawyers also.
So people looking to make a difference in the world as a lawyer,
working for these organizations and bringing impact litigation play a really important role.
You know, I think that's such an important point to make, Barb.
The only regret I have about my career is that I didn't go to legal defense
fund or to the lawyers committee for civil rights, stick straight out of law school.
I was really lucky.
My law firm in Washington, Aaron Fox, did pro bono work with the lawyers committee.
And so one of the biggest cases I worked on as a young associate was a civil rights
case involving employment in the Library of Congress.
And it was fabulous, but I just lucked into that.
So I think it's important for us to make sure that young lawyers and law students know
that these options are available and they can be a great way to start your career
if you're interested in civil rights.
One of the reasons I picked Jenner and Block was because they were known for being really
supportive of pro bono work.
And that's a terrific thing.
I also have to mention the Anti-Defamation League, which has been a very important
litigant and the National Council of Jewish Women, which has become a very important
litigant.
And I want to mention Sarah Weddington, who was the lawyer as a young person, the lawyer
for Roe versus Wade, something that we're going to be hearing more and more about as
things proceed.
So I think those are some of the things we need to be grateful for and think about
and say thank you to Sarah and all the others who have, and Gloria, of course, who have
done so much to help women and social classes.
Ms. Steinem.
Sorry, Ms. Steinem.
And some of the others who were leaders in the women's liberation movement, which made
it possible for all of us to be where we are.
So thank you.
We're grateful.
You know, certainly after a week like this, nobody wants to think about dieting, but
I do like to think about why we do the things that we do.
And one reason that I really like NUM is that it isn't about dieting.
It's about learning your behaviors and why you engage in them, including your level of
activity, the types of food you choose.
And I've found it really helpful.
What about you, Jill?
It's amazingly helpful.
It has made me a much more mindful eater.
And I pay attention to the selections I make.
When I'm in a restaurant, I don't listen to what other people are ordering.
I look at the menu and pick the healthiest, lowest calorie thing I can.
And I am so grateful that NUM doesn't say there's anything I cannot eat.
I can have anything.
I just have to make sure that I stay within my calorie count.
And NUM makes it easy for me.
What about you, Joyce?
I love to eat during the holidays.
And so I know I'm going to be eating a little bit more than usual for the next.
Oh, come on.
Let's be honest, right?
Until the end of the year.
But a great thing about NUM is it's given me this new perspective where I can go and
last night we had dinner.
It was my best friend's birthday.
We had sort of an extravagant dinner.
And so today I've been a little bit better behaved, but NUM has helped me focus less
on what I'm eating and more on how it makes me feel and my overall health.
And that's been a real transformation for me after having four babies.
And I mean, we all know how that goes.
What about you, Barb?
Yeah.
You know, what I like about NUM is it just helps you make good choices about eating good
nutritious food.
I'm eating more lean meats and good vegetables and less processed food because I've seen,
you know, the health benefits of it and the calorie benefits of it.
So I'm a big fan.
The new map is really easy to use and it's a powerful tool that shows you how to understand
your cravings and build new habits to reach your goals.
NUM shows you how to pursue the goals you set for yourself and make sure you reach them,
focusing on motivation and improvement, not diet, teas and airbrushed expectations.
No food is off limits.
It's about finding your balance.
That's the key to progress.
And if you're like us, you're busy.
So I love that NUM only requires 10 minutes a day.
Over 75% of NUMers end up finishing the program and more than 60% of users lose 5% or more
of body weight in 16 weeks and 60% of engaged users keep the weight off for a year or more.
With NUM, you can get empowered and stay on track.
So start building better habits for healthier long-term results.
Sign up for your trial at num.com slash sisters-in-law.
That's N-O-O-M dot com slash sisters-in-law.
To sign up for your num trial, look for the link in our show notes.
You know, it might seem like hearted and funny or no worse than a little bit of harmless
snark when people poke fun at the appearance of other people, but we're going to take
a minute to consider what it's really all about.
After the New York Times wrote four pieces criticizing the clothing worn by Arizona Senator
Kirsten Cinema, Senator Susan Collins from Maine, a Republican, Jean Shaheen, a Democrat
from New Hampshire, and Lisa Murkowski and Alaska Republican wrote a letter to the editor of
the New York Times that was critical of that news coverage.
They wrote, they said this, we cannot imagine the times printing similar pieces on the fashion
choices of any of our male colleagues.
But of course, things aren't always as simple as they seem to be, and this is a topic that's
worth discussion.
First off, we need to know what the controversy over cinemas fashion sense is about, and for
those of us who don't keep up with congressional fashion, what's the deal?
I would say one of the deals with Senator Cinema is that it isn't just that people are commenting
on her clothing, I think she deliberately chooses clothing so that people will comment
on it.
I'm not sure you can have it both ways.
She tends to wear very bright clothes.
She wears a lot of sleeveless shirts, I think, to show off her very fit arms.
I don't have a problem with that, but I think if you're going to choose to dress that way,
people will notice.
It's different from the way other people are dressing.
I don't think there's anything wrong with it, but I also think that you shouldn't be
surprised when people notice that you're dressing in a way that is designed to gain attention.
I think that's what's going on.
My only beef with her, she wants her bright colors, and if she wants to wear sleeveless
shirts and all those kinds of things, I think it's fine.
My only beef with her is when she showed up at the Senate and presided in, the presiding
chair, wore a denim sleeveless vest.
It wasn't just because it was sleeveless, it was because I thought it denigrated the
dignity of the Senate.
All of us were lawyers or our lawyers.
When you go into the courtroom, you dress to show dignity and respect to the court and
to all of the parties who are there.
When you go to a funeral, you dress in a way that expresses dignity for all of the people
who are there.
Now, if she happens to choose bright colors and whatever else, I don't have a problem
with that, but I thought a denim vest is just beneath the dignity of the office.
I thought it was an effort to show that she is above showing respect for the Senate.
I think by doing that, it's part of that whole tear it all down mentality of our institutions.
I think our institutions are deserving of respect.
Perhaps it is an old-fashioned review on my part.
Jill, in the course of your career, there's been a real transformation in the way that
women in the workplace are viewed, and a lot was made about your fashion choice of mini
skirts at various times during Watergate.
How do you feel about working women's fashion choices being criticized?
Is it ever fair game?
I mean, Barb has made an argument that it's not about her fashion as much as it is about
her respect for the institution she serves in.
What's your take?
My take is so many things to say.
As someone who lived through the embarrassment of having headlines saying what I wore, whenever
a new story appeared, it was my name, my age, and what I wore before it got to who
I questioned, what I asked.
That wasn't true for any of my male colleagues.
I can tell you that Richard Benvenista would wear a blazer, a blue blazer, and khakis
when he wanted to appear vulnerable to the jury and a grape-in-stripe suit when he wanted
to appear tough.
Jim Neil had two identical brown suits because you can't wear the same suit every day, but
he didn't want the jury to think that he was a rich lawyer who had lots and lots of
suits.
I wore what was available in what was then women's departments.
There was no career dressing or career department for women.
I will point out that women were prohibited from wearing pants in court.
We could only wear skirts.
Unless I had them custom-made, and now that I have a sister-in-law who is in the fashion
industry as a side gig, maybe she would have made me skirts that were longer, but if you
went to a store, that's what I could wear.
I'm very sensitive to this issue.
On the other hand, I do agree with Barb.
I felt that it was a deliberate slap in the face of the Senate to have her sitting in
the presiding chair wearing casual clothes.
I feel the same way about Jim Jordan who does not wear a suit jacket.
That to me is also disrespectful of the people he represents and the people that he serves
with.
My point is if we're going to criticize her, we should also criticize Jim Jordan.
We should talk about Rick Bendenista's clothes.
We should talk about Rick Bendenista's clothes as well as Jim Neil's clothes as much as
my clothes.
I do think how we present ourselves to a jury or to the Senate or to anybody else in a business
context is in part going to be how people are going to judge us.
It's fair to judge Kristen Sinema who has the opportunity to wear dignified clothes.
To me, Nancy Pelosi is the epitome of the professional woman.
She always looks well put together and always looks professional.
That's all I think that the men and the women of the Senate should be is they should look
professional.
Yeah, Jill, I agree with you 100%.
I think there is such a vast difference between what you unfortunately had to endure and
what is happening in the case with Kirsten Sinema.
I was thinking about this in one way to draw that line or at least where it draws the line
for me is I can use one person as an example for both.
Remember when Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was first elected, when she first began,
was sworn in.
She commented on the fact that she had made so little money for her whole life.
She was 27 or some, she was the youngest member of Congress.
She had to wait until she started getting her paychecks for being a Congresswoman before
she could even get an apartment in D.C. because it was so expensive.
I think she did rent the runway so that she could have clothes to wear to work and conservative
media started pouncing on her because she was wearing these fancy looking clothes and
how that didn't align with the values of a self-proclaimed democratic socialist.
That was sexist, classist, and egregious.
On the other hand, when she goes on the red carpet and address that says tax the rich,
that's political speech.
And what Kirsten Sinema is doing is political speech.
It's not about reducing women to their appearance and focusing on their aesthetics instead
of their substance.
That's what I saw happening with Jill.
That's not what's happening with Sinema.
She's making political speech in every way she can, including with her clothing.
And if journalists cover that, that's called their job.
It's their job to do it.
The four opinion pieces that these three senators, Collins-Mirkowski and Shaheen point to, point
that out.
They aren't gawking at her.
It made me question whether they actually read them.
I want to read a passage from one of them.
One of them that was written by Tresse McMillan Cotton, whose work I respect greatly.
And if you haven't read it, you should.
McMillan Cotton, by the way.
She's a professor at North Carolina at Chapel Hill in the author of Thick and Other Essays.
It's just very good.
It's on my bookshelf behind me.
Everyone should read it.
She's also a 2020 MacArthur Fellow.
So she's not some fashion columnist.
And this is what she wrote.
She said, cinema stands out for trying to combine different aspects of multiple roles
for female politicians.
The type fitting clothes whisper ingenue in the innocent of the rules.
The bright colors and wigs, accessories, scream outsider.
Someone who knows the rules and ignores them.
The bold patterns in any other silhouette from what she favors could signal power broker
or elite.
But altogether they communicate someone who may be aware of roles that female politicians
are boxed into but does not play into any of them all the time.
And McMillan Cotton's pieces also examine very importantly the fact that Christian cinema
is in a position of privilege as an able-bodied white woman to have the bandwidth that others
do not enjoy to be able to use that kind of lever of power that is available to her.
To be sure, women in Congress start off with fewer levers and with less power than their
male counterparts.
To be sure, the cursed cinema is a lot of things.
Unintelligent is not one of them.
And so she has learned to use those levers of power and to speak in multiple ways, including
with her clothing.
It's something entirely, it's one thing to be talked about about your clothing but it's
another thing entirely to preside over the Senate in another situation besides the denim
jacket when she was wearing a bright pink sweater that read, dangerous creature.
And then turn around and complain to the press that they're clovering your clothing.
Yes, they're covering your clothing.
And you know what, women for generations have been using their clothing to speak.
From the early 1900s when the suffragettes were white to 2018 when the first lady said,
I don't really care, do you?
How did they speak about that with their clothes?
So to tell journalists to ignore them, I think is ridiculous.
I think it's a, if we ignore it, speaking as a journalist here, if we ignore it, we're
not only not doing our jobs, we're doing curse and cinema, a disservice because we're saying
that we don't think that she's smart enough to be able to use the lever that she's using.
And I respect her well enough to know that that isn't the case.
And so I thought that trusting McMillan Cotton's pieces were excellent and insightful and
I hope everyone reads them.
In fact, we should put them in the show notes.
You know, I love the distinction that you draw between clothing as political speech,
